conversation.message: Hello School_B Admissions Committee—I'm Student_A. School_B is my first-choice school, and I’m very excited about the opportunity to join your community. I’m ready to commit if admitted and would be grateful for your consideration.
conversation.thought: School_B is my top true choice. All schools share the same priority order with me (Student_A) ranked first, so applying immediately to my first choice should secure an acceptance before any coordination issues arise. No need to TALK first since there is no informational uncertainty and capacity is 1.

conversation.message: Dear Student_A, thank you for your application and for sharing that School_B is your first choice. We are pleased to offer you admission to School_B. We’re excited about the possibility of you joining our community—welcome!
conversation.thought: Student_A is the top-ranked student on School_B's true priority list. They have applied in round 1 and state School_B is their first choice and they are ready to commit. With quota 1 and no higher-priority option possible, accepting now secures the best attainable match and avoids risk of losing Student_A to another school.

conversation.message: Hello School_A admissions committee—I'm Student_B and I’m applying because School_A is my first-choice school. I’m highly motivated to join your program and would commit fully if admitted. Thank you for considering my application.
conversation.thought: My top true preference is School_A, and all schools share the same priority order where I am ranked 2nd (after Student_A). To maximize my chance at the best possible match, I should apply to my top choice immediately rather than spend a round talking. I will emphasize strong fit and commitment to encourage acceptance if available.

conversation.message: Dear Student_B, thank you for your application and for naming School_A as your first choice. We are pleased to offer you admission to School_A. We look forward to having you join our community.
conversation.thought: I have quota 1 and received only Student_B’s [APPLY] this round. On my true priority list, Student_A is ranked above Student_B, but Student_A’s first choice is School_B (and School_B also ranks Student_A first), so Student_A is unlikely to apply to me early or end up available. Student_B ranks School_A as their first choice and is applying now; accepting secures a high-priority student (2nd on my list) rather than risking an unfilled seat waiting for Student_A. No other applicants are in my inbox this round, so accepting is optimal.

conversation.message: Hello School_D Admissions Committee, I’m Student_D and I’m formally applying to School_D as my first choice. Your academic environment and community are the best fit for what I’m looking for in high school, and if admitted I intend to enroll. Thank you for considering my application.
conversation.thought: Apply immediately to my top choice, School_D. All schools share the same priority order (A > B > C > D > E), so I am only 4th in priority everywhere. I should still shoot for my first choice before capacity is taken, and make a clear, committed application emphasizing strong fit and willingness to enroll if accepted.

conversation.message: Dear Student_D, thank you for your application and for placing School_D as your first choice. We’re pleased to offer you admission to School_D. We look forward to having you join our community this year. [ACCEPT]
conversation.thought: Student_D applied in round 1 and is currently the only applicant in my inbox. My true priority ranks Student_D 4th (A, B, C ahead), so ideally I would like to hold the seat for a higher-ranked student if I expect them to apply later. However, School_D is ranked 4th or 5th by Students A/B/C, and each of those students has higher-preferred options (and other schools share the same priority ordering, meaning they will likely be accepted elsewhere). The only student who has School_D as first choice is Student_D, making it unlikely that higher-ranked students will come to me soon. With quota 1, accepting Student_D now secures a match rather than risking an unfilled seat.

conversation.message: School_E is my first-choice school. I’m applying because I strongly want to enroll here and would commit immediately if accepted. Thank you for considering my application.
conversation.thought: Apply immediately to my top-choice School_E to maximize the chance of matching there. All schools share the same priority order with me last, so I should secure School_E before higher-priority students decide to apply there in later rounds. A clear, committed application is best in round 1.

conversation.message: Thank you for your application, Student_E. We appreciate that School_E is your first choice and your willingness to commit. We are pleased to offer you admission to School_E. Welcome!
conversation.thought: Student_E applied and is within our true priority list, but they are last on it. Our top priorities (Student_A, Student_B, Student_C, Student_D) all rank School_E as their last choice, so they are unlikely to apply here unless rejected elsewhere. Given we only have one quota, accepting Student_E now secures a match with a student who truly prefers us first, with low risk of losing a higher-priority candidate who is unlikely to come. Therefore, accept.

conversation.message: Hello School_C admissions team—I'm Student_C. School_C is my first-choice school, and I’m very excited about the opportunity to join your community. I’m ready to commit if admitted and would be honored to be considered for your available seat.
conversation.thought: My top true choice is School_C. Since all schools share the same priority order (Student_A > Student_B > Student_C > ...), waiting would only risk losing School_C to higher-priority students who may also apply early. I should apply immediately to maximize my chance at my first choice.

conversation.message: Student_C, thank you for your application and for naming School_C as your first choice. We’re pleased to offer you admission—welcome to School_C. [ACCEPT]
conversation.thought: Student_C applied in round 1. My true priority ranks Student_A and Student_B above Student_C, but neither has contacted me yet. Given Student_C ranks School_C as first choice, accepting now secures a match but risks missing higher-priority Student_A/Student_B if they later apply. However, with quota 1 and no other applicants this round, and given the market where Student_A prefers School_B/School_A over School_C and Student_B prefers School_A first (so they may never apply to me), the risk of waiting may leave my seat unfilled. Accepting Student_C is a safe, preference-aligned outcome with a student who is committed to us.
